definition: the empty city stratagem (in which Zhuge Liang presents himself as unperturbed while making it evident that his city is undefended, hoping his adversary will suspect an ambush)/double bluff
empty/air/sky/in vain
to empty/vacant/unoccupied/space/leisure/free time
city walls/city/town/CL:座[zuo4],道[dao4],個|个[ge4]
surname Ji
to calculate/to compute/to count/to regard as important/to plan/ruse/meter/gauge
lit. to sing “The Empty City Stratagem” (idiom)/fig. to put up a bluff to conceal one's weakness/(jocularly) (of a place etc) to be empty/(of one's stomach) to be rumbling

sentences.english: The only problem I have with my mailbox lately is that it's often empty.
sentences.chinese: 最近我遇到的唯一个难题是我的邮箱常常唱空城计。

sentences.english: The only problem I have with my mailbox lately is that it’s often empty.
sentences.chinese: 最近我遇到的唯一个难题是我的邮箱常常唱空城计。

sentences.english: The most interesting episode is the Empty-town Plan of Mr.
sentences.chinese: 感触最深的是诸葛亮的空城计。

sentences.english: We can't leave no one to keep an eye on things.
The Empty City Trick presents a kind of seesaw movement between the works and the viewers.
sentences.chinese: “空城计”上演了一场作品与观者之间的拉锯运动。

definition: lit. using straw boats to borrow arrows (idiom, from 三國演義|三国演义[San1 guo2 Yan3 yi4])/fig. to use others' manpower and resources for one's own ends
interlocked stratagems/CL:條|条[tiao2]
lit. to use the eastern wind (idiom)/fig. to use sb's help

Romance of the Three Kingdoms by Luo Guanzhong 羅貫中|罗贯中[Luo2 Guan4 zhong1], one of the Four Classic Novels of Chinese literature/a fictional account of the Three Kingdoms at the break-up of the Han around 200 AD, consistently portraying Liu Bei's Shu Han 劉備|刘备, 蜀漢|蜀汉 as virtuous heroes and Cao Cao's Wei 曹操, 魏 as tyrannical villains
feigned surrender
to dramatize historical events/novel or play on historical theme

Battle of Redcliff of 208 at Chibi in Huangzhou district 黃州區|黄州区 of Huanggang city 黄冈, a decisive defeat of Cao Cao 曹操 at the hands of southern kingdom of Wu/famous episode in the Romance of the Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义

lit. secretly crossing the Wei River 渭河[Wei4 He2] at Chencang (idiom, refers to a stratagem used by Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] in 206 BC against Xiang Yu 項羽|项羽[Xiang4 Yu3] of Chu)/fig. to feign one thing while doing another/to cheat under cover of a diversion
lit. to besiege 魏[Wei4] and rescue 趙|赵[Zhao4] (idiom)/fig. to relieve a besieged ally by attacking the home base of the besiegers

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
Huarong Road (traditional puzzle involving sliding wooden blocks, loosely based on an episode in Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义[San1 guo2 Yan3 yi4])
stratagem of sowing dissension/CL:條|条[tiao2]
Sima Yi (179-251), warlord under Cao Cao and subsequently founder of the Jin dynasty
the trick of injuring oneself to gain the enemy's confidence/CL:條|条[tiao2]
The Thirty-Six Stratagems, a Chinese essay used to illustrate a series of stratagems used in politics, war, and in civil interaction/all the possible schemes and stratagems
to threaten the east and strike to the west (idiom)/to create a diversion
